moves.1. e4: Hello. I am a fairly new member to this site (only a few weeks), and I have completed 3 games, and this is the only one with any quality whatsoever, but it is quite boring. (Just so you know, I am rated about 1700 on chess.com, and am about 1600 rated CFC.
moves.1... c5: The Sicilian is my usual weapon with Black, and I play the Budapest (1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 e5) against d4.
moves.2. Nf3 d6: The Kopec variation. Can lead to Dragons (g6) and Najdorfs (a6) and Scheveningens (e6) and Classicals (Nc6)
moves.3. d4: The Open Variation, willing to oblidge and let Black choose the variation.
moves.3... cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6: But before any opening choosing, Black almost always interjects 4...Nf6.
moves.5. Nc3 a6: I choose the Najdorf, which I have been playing for a few years now.
moves.6. Bg5 e6 7. Bd3: You don't see this move as much as more agressive 7.Bc4, 7.f4 or even 7.Qe2.
moves.7... Be7 8. Nf3: ?! This just blocks f4, which is common in 6.Bg5 variations, and besides, you shouldn't be moving the same piece twice in the opening unless it's nessecary.
moves.9... Qc7: The typical outpost for the Queen, watching over the c-file, and potentially, the h2-b8 diagonal. Part of the point of a6 and e6 was to keep an opposing Knight off d5 and b5 to protect the Queen's square.
moves.10. O-O b5 11. Re1 Bb7 12. Be3: ?! Moving another piece twice in the opening. The computer likes 12.a4.
moves.12... Nc5: c5 is a nice square for the Knight, and if he takes, I get an open file leading to his Queen.
moves.13. Bxc5 dxc5 14. e5 Nd5 15. Nxd5 Bxd5: I chose this capture to keep the open d-file.
moves.16. Be4 Rd8 17. Qe2: Wisely removing the Queen from my Rook's vision.
moves.17... c4: I just had a gut feeling sort of about this move, 17...Bc4 didn't seem right, and 17...0-0 just seemed premature.
moves.18. c3 O-O 19. Rad1 Bxe4 20. Qxe4 Rxd1: I offered a draw here, and he accepted. After 21.Rxd1 Rd8, thew position is simplifying. In fact, it is so equal, the computer rates this position as 1/100th of a pawn better for me.
